title: LME aluminium cash offer slips to USD 3,081 as opening stocks fall 4.6% on January 8
summary: London Metal Exchange aluminium prices eased on January 8, with the cash offer declining to about $3,081 per tonne, down roughly 0.36% from the prior session.[1] The 3‑month contract also weakened, while exchange stocks fell and warrant positioning shifted, indicating tight but volatile market conditions.[1]

title: Aluminum Futures Hover Near 3-Year High on Tight Supply
summary: Aluminum futures in the UK traded around $3,090 per tonne on January 8, staying close to a more than three‑year high amid mounting signs of tighter supply.[2] Prices are up over 8% in the past month and more than 21% year‑on‑year as China keeps a firm cap on output and global demand remains resilient.[2]

title: NALCO Shares Skyrocket to Record High as Aluminum Prices Breach $3,000 Mark
summary: National Aluminium Company (NALCO) shares jumped about 6% to a record high after global aluminium prices climbed above $3,000 per tonne, the highest level in more than three years.[4] The rally is being driven by capped smelting capacity in China, production constraints in Europe due to high power costs, and strong demand from construction and renewable energy sectors.[4]

title: January 9 Aluminum Inventory Update: Significant Drop in Ingots, Slight Increase in Billets
summary: SMM reports that Chinese aluminum prices have been fluctuating at elevated levels after touching about 23,000 yuan per tonne this week, as inventory data show a notable decline in ingot stocks and a small rise in billet inventories.[5] The combination of high prices and changing stock structure is pressuring billet processing fees and shaping near‑term market dynamics.[5]

title: China's aluminium industry cost to fall in January – alumina as key driver
summary: SMM reports that Chinese aluminium smelters are expected to see **lower production costs in January 2026**, mainly due to a surplus-driven decline in alumina prices and easing auxiliary material costs.[1] Operating alumina capacity may edge down month-on-month, but overall fundamentals remain in surplus, while electricity costs are projected to rebound, slightly offsetting the savings.[1]

title: January 9 Aluminum Inventory Update: Significant Drop in Ingots, Slight Increase in Billets
summary: SMM’s latest daily update shows **social inventory of aluminum ingots in major Chinese consumption regions at about 455,000 tonnes on January 9**, indicating a notable drawdown.[5] Billet inventories, by contrast, recorded a slight increase, suggesting diverging short-term demand patterns between different semi-finished aluminum products.[5]

title: ASUS Honored with Eight CES 2026 Innovation Awards
summary: ASUS received eight CES 2026 Innovation Awards for products spanning AI, sustainability, and creative technologies, highlighting its focus on greener materials and processes.[4] A key advance is its Ceraluminum™ process for aluminum, which strengthens the metal using a low‑voltage, low‑energy, fully recyclable treatment that reduces environmental impact while improving durability.[4]

title: CES Innovation Awards 2026 Honoree: Portable SSD T7 Resurrected
summary: Samsung’s Portable SSD T7 Resurrected earned a CES 2026 Innovation Award for its circular-design concept built around a 100% recycled aluminum enclosure.[6] The device extends Samsung’s use of aluminum scrap from smartphone production and pairs it with recycled paper packaging, serving as a flagship example of the company’s broader circular-materials and sustainability strategy.[6]

title: HRC Steel Price Edges Lower But Remains Up 33% Year-on-Year
summary: Hot-rolled coil (HRC) steel prices slipped to about 936–938 USD/ton, down around 0.2% from the previous day but still more than 30% higher than a year earlier.[1] Over the past month, HRC steel has gained roughly 3%, and Trading Economics models project prices could approach 960 USD/ton by the end of the quarter and exceed 1,030 USD/ton over 12 months, signaling expectations of continued firmness in the market.[1]

title: China's Baosteel Hikes January 2026 Prices Amid Rising Raw Material Costs and Market Optimism
summary: Baosteel has increased its steel prices for January 2026, ending three straight months of flat listings, citing higher raw material costs and improved sentiment about future demand.[4] Market sources note that although current steel demand in China remains weak, the price hikes reflect expectations of better conditions later in 2026.[4]

title: Raw Material Prices Rise Sharply at the Start of the Year
summary: Key industrial metals, including copper, aluminium and nickel, have posted strong price gains in early 2026, driven by tight supply, production constraints and rising demand.[3] Stainless steel futures on the Shanghai Futures Exchange have climbed by just under 2% in the past two weeks, with the new EU CBAM carbon tax also adding cost pressures and provoking pushback from major trading partners.[3]

title: Poland reduced steel production by 25% y/y in November
summary: Poland’s steel production fell by about a quarter year‑on‑year in November, reflecting continued weakness in European steel demand and pressure from cheaper imports.[3] The decline highlights broader underutilization of capacity across the EU as mills cut output in response to low margins and subdued construction and manufacturing activity.[3]

title: Austria increased steel production by 7.6% y/y in November
summary: Austria posted a 7.6% year‑on‑year rise in steel production in November, contrasting with declines in several other European countries.[3] The increase suggests better capacity utilization at Austrian mills, likely supported by stronger export orders or domestic industrial demand.[3]

title: Spain increased steel production by 5.4% y/y in 1H 2025
summary: Spanish steelmakers boosted output by 5.4% in the first half of 2025 compared with the same period a year earlier.[3] The growth indicates improved use of installed capacity, supported by recovering construction and infrastructure activity in Spain.[3]

title: Global steel production fell by 5.8% y/y in June
summary: World crude steel production declined 5.8% year‑on‑year in June, signaling a broad-based reduction in output across major producing regions.[3] The drop reflects persistent challenges from weak demand, high input costs, and environmental policy pressures on capacity utilization.[3]

title: ArcelorMittal temporarily shuts down blast furnace in Poland due to import pressure
summary: ArcelorMittal has temporarily idled a blast furnace in Poland in response to intense pressure from low‑priced steel imports.[3] The shutdown reduces local production capacity and underscores competitiveness issues facing EU integrated mills amid rising imports and sluggish domestic demand.[3]

title: France reduced steel production by 18.1% year-on-year in June
summary: French steel production fell 18.1% year‑on‑year in June, one of the steeper declines among major EU producers.[3] The cutback points to significantly underused capacity as French mills respond to weak industrial output and competition from imported steel.[3]

title: World crude steel production for 70 countries down 4.6% in November 2025
summary: Crude steel production across 70 reporting countries reached 140.1 million tonnes in November 2025, down 4.6% compared with November 2024.[5] The contraction highlights reduced operating rates and capacity utilization in multiple regions amid softer global demand and tighter environmental regulations.[5]

title: Steel imports up 11.0% in October vs. September
summary: U.S. steel imports in October rose 11% compared with September, indicating increased reliance on foreign supply even as domestic producers operate below full capacity.[6] Higher imports may further pressure U.S. mill utilization rates, particularly in flat‑rolled products exposed to price‑sensitive buyers.[6]

title: El-Marakby Steel launches a new plant to localize production inputs
summary: El‑Marakby Steel plans to invest about EGP 1 billion (around USD 21 million) in a new plant aimed at localizing production inputs and expanding its product portfolio.[4] The project will add capacity in Egypt’s steel value chain, reducing dependence on imported semifinished materials and enhancing supply security.[4]

title: Turbulence ahead: how current and future trade measures affect steel and aluminum capacity decisions
summary: Clyde & Co analyzes how U.S. tariffs of around 50% on most steel and aluminum imports are reshaping global capacity decisions and encouraging more localized production.[7] The report notes that persistent Section 232 tariffs and retaliatory measures are prompting foreign producers to consider new steel and aluminum facilities inside the U.S. to bypass trade barriers.[7]

title: ClarkDietrich launches industry-first embodied carbon calculator for steel framing
summary: ClarkDietrich announced what it calls the steel framing industry’s first embodied carbon calculator, aimed at helping builders and designers quantify and reduce the carbon footprint of cold-formed steel products used in construction.[6] The digital tool is intended to support more sustainable material choices and to align steel framing with emerging low‑carbon building standards and reporting requirements.[6]

title: Copper prices near all-time high: Structural shift or speculative spike? Here’s where the red metal is headed
summary: The article reports that copper prices are trading near record levels, driven by a mix of tightening global supply, strong structural demand from electrification, and speculative flows.[1][3] It examines whether the current rally signals a long-term structural bull market or a short‑term speculative spike, and outlines key risks such as Chinese demand softness and potential policy shocks.[1][5]

title: Bernstein issues new copper prices target for 2026
summary: Bernstein forecasts that copper will average $11,500 per tonne in Q1 2026 before easing to around $10,000 per tonne in the second half as momentum fades.[2] The note attributes current record‑high prices above $13,000 per tonne to supply disruptions, electrification‑driven demand, and speculative activity, but warns that slower EV sales and substitution could trigger a correction.[2][5]

title: Period of elevated copper prices overextended: analysts
summary: S&P Global reports that LME copper has repeatedly set new records, climbing from around $11,000/mt in late October to over $13,200/mt in early January, levels many analysts see as exceeding fundamentals.[5] While StoneX still expects high average prices near $11,490/mt in 2026, analysts highlight weakening downstream demand in China and diverging views between bullish Western funds and more bearish Chinese traders.[5]

title: Copper Hits Record Highs Amid Tariff Fears and Supply Disruptions
summary: The piece notes that on January 6, 2026, benchmark copper prices on the LME reached about $13,187 per tonne, a fresh record and a 1.5% daily jump.[6] It links the surge to worries over potential new US tariffs on refined metals, supply disruptions at key mines, and ongoing tightness in concentrate availability.[5][6]

title: Goldman Sachs raises first-half copper price forecast
summary: Goldman Sachs has lifted its copper price forecast for the first half of 2026 to $12,750/mt from $11,525/mt, reflecting the stronger‑than‑expected rally and persistent tightness in supply.[7] The bank cites robust demand from electrification and infrastructure alongside constrained mine output, while still anticipating some moderation from peak spot levels above $13,000/mt.[2][7]

title: Copper futures retreat slightly from record highs
summary: Trading Economics notes that copper futures recently pulled back to around $5.79–$5.8 per pound after hitting all‑time highs above $6 per pound, as some investors took profits.[3][4] Despite the minor correction, prices remain up more than 35% year‑on‑year, supported by expectations of Chinese monetary easing and ongoing concerns over global supply.[3]

title: China's industrial buyers shun copper after prices hit record
summary: Chinese copper demand has significantly declined following record price surges, with fabricators struggling to pass higher costs to factories. Refined copper stockpiles have climbed to eight-year highs, and smelters are exporting surplus inventory at steep discounts as domestic demand remains subdued.

title: Period of elevated copper prices overextended: analysts
summary: Analysts warn that copper prices have exceeded sustainable levels due to supply disruptions and speculation. StoneX forecasts 2026 copper prices averaging $11,490/mt, while Chinese traders hold bearish positions contrasting with Western bullish sentiment.

title: Glencore, Rio Tinto in Merger Discussions
summary: Glencore and Rio Tinto are in preliminary merger discussions that could create a company valued at over $388 billion. The discussions occur amid surging copper prices exceeding $13,000/tonne, with S&P Global projecting copper demand will reach 42 million tonnes by 2040 while production peaks at 33 million tonnes in 2030.

title: Goldman Sachs raises first-half copper price forecast
summary: Goldman Sachs increased its copper price forecast for the first half of 2026 to $12,750 per metric ton, up from its previous forecast of $11,525 per ton.

title: ‘Substantial Shortfall’ in Copper Supply Widens as the Race for AI and Growing Defense Spending Add to Accelerating Demand, New S&P Global Study Finds
summary: S&P Global releases a new study warning that accelerating demand for copper from electrification, AI data centers, renewable energy, EVs, and defense risks turning copper from an enabler of innovation into a bottleneck for growth.[2] The report stresses that closing the looming supply gap will require major investment, new mines, expanded recycling, and policy and permitting reforms to support a more resilient and sustainable copper value chain.[2][1]

title: The AI and Defense Boom Threatens to Exacerbate Global Copper Shortage, Warns S&P
summary: An S&P-linked news item highlights that booming investment in AI and defense is intensifying pressure on already tight global copper supply.[6] It echoes findings that without accelerated mine development and innovation across the copper supply chain, copper shortages could hinder electrification and technology deployment critical to climate and security goals.[6][1]

title: SMM Nickel Midday Review: Nickel Prices Continue to Correct on January 9
summary: SMM reports that China’s #1 refined nickel price range fell to 135,800–148,000 yuan/mt on January 9, with the average at 141,900 yuan/mt, down 7,150 yuan/mt from the previous trading day, reflecting a sharp pullback after the recent rally.[1] The most-traded SHFE 2602 nickel contract also dropped about 4% intraday, as market sentiment shifted from frenzy to caution amid a stand-off between bullish policy expectations and weak spot demand, with traders closely watching Indonesia’s nickel policy implementation.[1]

title: Global Nickel Market Recalibrates After Explosive Trading Week
summary: INN notes that three‑month LME nickel prices stabilized near US$17,900/t on Thursday, January 8, after a week of extreme volatility in which prices surged more than 10% before retreating.[3] The article attributes the swings to heavy Chinese buying, uncertainty over Indonesia’s mining quota approvals, and sharply higher LME inventories (up over 300% since early 2025), suggesting the market is now recalibrating and that future moves will hinge on policy enforcement rather than demand.[3]

title: Copper and Nickel Fall on Profit-Taking
summary: According to a market report carried by Hellenic Shipping News, LME nickel fell 3.8% to about US$17,205/t as traders took profits after the recent sharp rally and as Indonesia held back from disclosing its 2026 mining output quota.[7] The lack of clarity on Indonesian supply, following earlier price spikes driven by expectations of tighter output, prompted a pullback across base metals, with both copper and nickel easing from recent highs.[7]

title: Nickel is the leading base metal on the market due to uncertainty about Indonesian output
summary: The article reports that nickel has become the strongest-performing base metal as traders react to Indonesia’s plan to reduce 2026 nickel mining production quotas, a move designed to support prices. It notes that benchmark LME and Shanghai nickel contracts fell sharply after a recent rally of more than 30%, with analysts warning that oversupply and rising inventories could cap further gains, while policy uncertainty over Indonesian output remains the key driver.[2]

title: Global Nickel Market Recalibrates After Explosive Trading Week
summary: This piece describes how nickel prices stabilized after a highly volatile week marked by double‑digit daily gains and subsequent pullbacks, driven mainly by evolving Indonesian production policies and heavy Chinese buying.[3] It highlights that PT Vale Indonesia temporarily halted mining at its Pomalaa and Bahodopi operations due to delays in 2026 production plan approvals, cutting output to about 30% of normal capacity, while broader uncertainty over final quota levels continues to influence market expectations for supply and capacity.[3]

title: Pressure for Indonesian quota U-turn is a risk for nickel price rally
summary: The article analyzes Indonesia’s decision to cut nickel mining quotas, which helped push nickel prices to near 19‑month highs, and examines the risk that political and industry pressure could force the government to reverse course.[7] It notes that Indonesia accounts for about 70% of global nickel production (around 3.8 million tonnes last year) and that many new projects are set to start in the second half of the year, raising the possibility that quotas could be relaxed later and allow production and capacity to increase despite the initial curbs.[7]

title: Indonesia to set 2026 coal output quota at around 600 million tons, will adjust nickel quota, minister says
summary: Covering comments from Indonesia’s energy minister, this report states that the government plans to set the 2026 coal output quota at about 600 million tons and will also adjust nickel production quotas as part of efforts to restore market balance.[5] The minister reiterates that reductions will apply across commodities, including nickel, signaling potential constraints on future nickel output and capacity relative to earlier expectations.[5]

title: Extending product lifecycles: The missing link in circular economy
summary: This article argues that extending the lifespan of industrial and consumer products is critical to reducing waste, emissions, and resource use in a circular economy. It highlights that sectors like renewable energy and electric vehicles face major supply challenges as demand for critical minerals such as nickel and cobalt is projected to double by 2040, and describes engineering innovations—including advanced coatings, 3D-printed low‑carbon materials, and resilience-based design—that can cut material throughput and improve sustainability.[2]

title: Copper Cables: Antitrust Launches Investigation into Alleged Cartel, Prysmian and Nexans Fall on the Stock Exchange
summary: Italy’s Antitrust Authority (AGCM) has opened an investigation into major low‑voltage copper cable manufacturers for an alleged price‑fixing cartel dating back to 2005, involving companies such as Prysmian Cavi e Sistemi Italia, Nexans’ La Triveneta Cavi, and several other Italian producers.[1] The authority carried out inspections at company headquarters, distributors, and a wholesalers’ federation; analysts currently expect only a negligible impact on Prysmian, as Italian low‑voltage copper cables account for less than 3% of its revenues.[1]
